survey.title: PROPOSED BEST PRACTICE GUIDELINES TO CLARIFY THE MEANING OF “NONCOMMERCIAL” IN THE CREATIVE COMMONS LICENSES

screen.title: Welcome to the NC survey

question.title:
This NonCommercial survey is based on the current discussion draft of the “NonCommercial Guidelines” that were posted to the Creative Commons weblog and the cc-licenses list on January 6, 2006. The purpose of this survey is to get your feedback on what qualifies as a noncommercial use under the Creative Commons licenses that include a “NonCommercial” license limitation (specifically, the Attribution-NonCommercial license, the Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike license, and the Attribution-NonCommercial-NoDerivatives license.

To complete this survey, please click the “Next” button below. The survey generally takes no more than 5 minutes to complete. To navigate back to an earlier question, please use the “Back” button provided at the bottom of each survey page. Do not try to navigate by using “Back” button of your browser.

When you reach a conclusion page of the survey (i.e., one that tells you whether or not the proposed use is a commercial or noncommercial use), you will have the option of providing us with comments on the survey result. You need to click the “Submit” button so that we receive these comments.

screen.title: Section B: Nature of the user

question.title:
Is the person making a use of an NC-licensed work an “allowable NC user” under the noncommercial license condition? Allowable NC users are:
  1. an individual,
  2. a nonprofit educational institution/library,
  3. a Nonprofit organization as defined under US1 or equivalent law, (together with (1) and (2) “allowable NC users”), or
  4. A commercial copy shop, ISP, search engine, content aggregator, blog aggregator site or similar service provider who, in the course of providing a service at the direction of the allowable NC user, may exercise a right licensed under the Creative Commons license.

option.onselect: The proposed use would be a Commercial Use

screen.title: Section C. Nature of the use: Advertising

question.title: Is the NC-licensed content being used in an advertisement for third party products or services? For example, Brian’s CC BY-NC licensed photo of the Eiffel Tower being used to advertise bottled water made by Shaun’s company.

option.onselect: The proposed use would be a Commercial Use

screen.title: Section C. Nature of the use: Advertising

question.title: Is viewing of an advertisement for third party products or services required as a condition of accessing or viewing the NC-licensed content (eg. “click-through” advertising)? For example, in order to view Mary’s CC BY-NC-ND licensed article, does a person first see an advertisement for a car.

option.onselect: The proposed use would be a Commercial Use

screen.title: Section C. Nature of the use: Advertising

question.title: Is the NC-licensed work being used in connection with advertisements for third party products or services where the NC-licensed work is the primary draw or a is substantial amount, both qualitatively and quantitatively? For example, a podcast consisting solely of CC BY-NC-SA licensed music have ads for a record store at the start and end of the podcast.

option.onselect: The proposed use would be a Commercial Use

screen.title: Section D. Conditions on Use: For Services Provided

question.title: Is money changing hands in exchange for a service provided in connection with the NC-licensed work? For example, a copy shop charging for the service of making a copy or a search engine receiving ad revenue for ads served up when searching for NC-licensed content.

option.onselect: Is money changing hands for a service being provided to

question.title: Is money changing hands as a condition of using another work that includes an NC-licensed work, where the NC-licesned work is either the primary draw or a substantial amount, whether qualitatively or quantitatively (e.g., where an NC-licensed image is used on the cover of and as a central part of a book that is sold commercially)?

option.onselect: The proposed use would be a Commercial Use

option.onselect: Provided that there is no charge associated with diectly accessing the work

screen.title: Section G. Conditions on Use: Derivative Works

question.title: Is the money changing hands in connection with a derivative use of an NC licensed work? Money can change hands one of these three ways; select the one most appropriate to your use.

option.onselect: The proposed use would be a Commercial Use

question.option: As a condition of using a derivative work based on an NC-licensed work, of which the original NC-licensed work is the primary draw or a substantial amount, whether qualitatively or quantitatively, of that derivative work (eg. where a commercially released short film is made using a CC BY-NC licensed piece of music and the music is the sole audio component of the film)

option.onselect: The proposed use would be a NonCommercial Use

question.option: As a condition of using a derivative work based on an NC-licensed work, of which the original NC-licensed work is not the primary draw or is an insubstantial amount, both qualitatively and quantitatively, of that derivative work (e.g., a commercially released mash-up is made of a piece of CC BY-NC licensed music that is used only incidentally in the mash-up)

option.onselect: The proposed use would be a NonCommercial Use

question.option: As an optional contribution (e.g. a tip jar, donations, membership drive) for an allowed NC user that uses the verbatim NC-licensed work or another work that includes a verbatim NC-licensed work
